This morning I found a group packages left on the corner of my yard right next to a public sidewalk. Five Amazon Prime packages, for addresses other than mine, had been dumped on my property by, I presume, the Amazon Prime delivery person. I called Amazon Customer Service and spoke to a representative who was argumentative and unhelpful. I explained that these were all Prime packages for people who were paying Amazon a subscription fee in order to ensure quick, safe, responsible delivery. I told her that I live a 15-minute drive away from the Robbinsville, NJ Amazon Warehouse Fulfillment Center at 50 Canton Way and did not understand why this problem could not be resolved today. The Customer Service rep said she would file a report, but did not ask for any of the tracking numbers for the packages. She then told me just to leave the packages outside and someone would be by-- sometime--to pick them up. I waited all day for that to happen.Late this afternoon I called Amazon Customer Service again. This representative was more pleasant and helpful. Apparently, the first Customer Service rep with whom I had spoken did not even file a report when this rep looked to find it. This second rep took tracking numbers with which to file a report and said it would take three days for a pickup to happen for redelivery, which is Amazon's policy, even for Prime subscribers! Again, I said that was unacceptable. For example, Amazon now delivers prescription medications and what if someone is waiting for a prescription to be delivered. I told the rep a three-day redelivery for Prime does not make sense, is bad business, and that I would deliver four of the five packages to the houses whose locations in my neighborhood I know. As for the fifth package, Amazon will actually have to have someone do their job and come to pick it up for redelivery. I also expressed that I do not work for Amazon. With that being said however, the four packages I said I would deliver are now at their correct addresses.Amazon Prime buyer/subscriber beware. I would have left a rating of "zero" if that had been an option. Perhaps Amazon's founder and former CEO, instead of now spending billions of dollars looking for a new planet on which to live (funded in part by Amazon Prime subscribers), should have ensured that Amazon's workforce is valued, not recklessly overworked, that the employees are responsible, and Amazon has logical, work-flow procedures in place in order to deal with problems that are not so difficult to solve.

I can't begin to describe how far Amazon has fallen over the years.  I was a customer from the beginning.  I was with Prime shortly after it came out.  I seriously thought it was the best company in the world, until it wasn't.  Then it wasn't even close.  Amazon now has among the worst customer service I encounter anywhere.  It rivals Comcast and Verizon Fios for the worst service you can even conceive of.  There's literally no way to describe the thousand ways Amazon fails at basic stuff.  It's service is a nightmare now.  You're sent off to a foreign country, with people who are supremely unhelpful, with the simplest issues taking hours to resolve.  I'm over it.  I no longer trust Amazon.  It's that simple.  Most recent case in point: I called Synchrony Bank, the issuer of the Amazon store card, to pay my bill.  It said the balance was over $400, so I thought I'd go through to a live person and see what the purchases were, to make sure nothing was unauthorized.  I recognized every purchase, except one.  There was an $11 charge for Amazon digital services.  I knew I hadn't authorized any digital purchases, so told them to put me through to Amazon.  The Indian man I spoke with was completely unhelpful.  Mind you, I mean him or anyone else no disrespect for being foreign.  He spoke with a thick accent likely because English was his second language.  GOOD FOR HIM.  It's something to be proud of.  But it also makes it very difficult to take care of issues that have any degree of complexity at all. He insisted I definitely ordered Amazon Music Unlimited, because I played [unintelligible] on my Alexa device.  What was the name of it?  "It was [unintelligible]"  HUH?  SAY THAT AGAIN SLOWLY?  Literally, his accent was so thick I couldn't tell at all what he was saying.  After repeating it a fourth time, I made out the word "noise."  It hit me that Amazon was charging me $11 a month to play "brown noise" on my bedroom Alexa device.  I've played that as a background sleep noise for YEARS.  Didn't start in December.  I've literally played it for about 3-5 years, every single night.  Suddenly it apparently started charging me for it in December.  I never heard it ask me ANYTHING about a subscription and certainly never agreed to any such thing.  But that didn't convince this Amazon rep, who apparently could read my mind and insisted I absolutely did order it.  I grew increasingly annoyed, especially as he kept going silent for 20, 30, 40 seconds at a time without saying a word, no hold or anything.. just silence.  Finally I told him, "why are you being silent?  I don't know what you're doing."  He then hung up on me.  So much for customer service.  I called angrier now and spoke with a second rep.  She was so very sorry the first rep hung up on me.  If I would just take more time out of my Saturday night to explain everything all over again and verify myself again... which I had no choice but to do.  She took a complaint on the last rep, but said she couldn't help me.  I'd have to be transferred to Amazon music.  Mind you, by this time it's nearly 1 am in the morning on a Sunday morning.  She puts me on hold... and I wait and I wait and wait some more.  About 15 minutes she comes back and says "I'm sorry for the long wait.  I'm still in the queue to speak with Amazon music."  I told her I would wait.  She puts me back on hold... 20 minutes pass... 30 minutes pass... 40 minutes pass.  Finally I had to give up.  She never came back on the line to say anything.  Just the same canned music playing over and over and over and over on a loop.  Called again.  Asked for a supervisor, but my phone died because I'd been held on the line so long.  He didn't call back.  I gave up because I had to give up.  Otherwise, I'd have a stroke from my anger and high blood pressure.  Amazon, you suck. Every single time I have a problem now, this is what I encounter.  Amazon is no longer a great company.  It's a company that will cut every corner, that disrespects its customers and their time, and that cares only about its bottom line.  It will go the way of Sears because it deserves to.
